node.text:
ED/Addiction TW: I’ve been hesitant to call my eating issues an “addiction” because I didn’t want to, in any way, diminish the struggle that people have with substance abuse or chemical addictions. But, a few years ago, when I came to the realization that my compulsion to restrict my eating was one I’d have to fight for the rest of my life, it started to seem a lot like how people described recovering from drug addiction, cigarette addiction, alcohol addiction: the desire to consume these substances never completely subsides, so you have to be on guard, to some degree, forever.
.
@richroll recently released an excellent podcast with addiction expert, Anna Lembke, MD, and it was both illuminating and oddly soothing—like, it was ok to just admit, “yeah, what I have is an addiction, even if it’s not traditionally viewed that way.” Sometimes, naming these things can help with treating these things, you know? Or at least coping with them.
.
These days, I’ve been trying to teach myself to lean back a little—not necessarily on other people, but on the universe itself, trusting that there’s something out there that will not allow me to fall if my heart is pure.  It sounds naive and there are statistics out there that seem to prove this theory wrong—that the universe is callous and cruel. But, when you’re being asked to roll a boulder up an unending mountain, what else do you have if not the belief that your task is all part of something greater than yourself, something you can’t see, but great nonetheless? I don’t say these things to disown my mistakes, my achievements, my power—but to allow myself respite between the battles, a little break between the sprints, I suppose.
.
I don’t have all the answers, but sometimes I think that is the answer: getting comfortable with knowing there’s no easy resolution, there’s no finish line. Finding joy isn’t about stringing together an endless chain of happy moments; rather, it is an anchor that allows you to ride the waves of both elation and crushing disappointment, while always coming home.

node.title: TW: What I Eat In A Week & Discussing Addiction

node.text:
I’ve been calling my Dad “Daddy” since I can remember. You know that transition that most people make—from “Daddy” to “Dad” or, for Korean Americans, “Daddy” to “Appa”? I could never make the shift. It’s really hard for me to explain why. It’s like the language barrier, the cultural barrier—these already created so much distance between me and my Dad and I felt that calling him “Dad” required both of us to face things that neither was comfortable confronting.  We were both fumbling with a language that could never adequately capture who either of us is—him, more Korean than American and me, more American than Korean, or perhaps, both of us, somewhere in between, both of us with one foot in and one foot out of a boundary that seems to move however much we tried to keep things where they were, and somehow, the word “Daddy” was our anchor in all of this. So, when I heard Ji-Yoon, the main character in Sandra Oh’s new show, The Chair, call her dad “Daddy,” it was like “OMG, I’m not the only one then!!”
.
There are so many scenes in this show that beautifully represent moments from my own childhood, my own sometimes fraught relationship with my parents, and being a woman of color in a profession where there are so few of us.  But, one of the best things about this show is that it does so without advertising it. This is not a show that’s “rah rah, look Asian Representation hashtag!” It reveals our story as naturally as Omma peels a pear or flips some bindaetteok and in so doing, makes me feel seen in a way I’ve never experienced while watching TV before.
.
Thank you @iamsandraohinsta for beautifully playing Ji-Yoon as only you could. Thank you Amanda Peet for writing characters that look so much like me and my family.  Thank you @netflix for producing such an beautiful show.

node.title: Bindaetteok & My Chat With Sandra Oh

node.text:
The voiceover is what I had as my profile on Ok Cupid, which is how we met. Love—sustainable love—isn’t always easy for me. There were hurdles that I wasn’t always sure we’d make and challenges I couldn’t guarantee we’d withstand. And even today, after 3 years of being in “wedded bliss,” I know enough about life that promises and vows can be rewritten over time. So, while I can’t tell you what the future holds, I can tell you what today holds: my commitment to put as much work into our partnership as anything I’ve ever done in my life—more than my job, my marathons, my blog, my anything. Happy Anniversary, my love and darling and sweetheart. I am so grateful that God brought you into my life. 
📸: @kenny_kim

node.text: “When the cat’s away…” I used to love music. I once harbored the cliched hope of being a professional musician. But, adulting got in the way. Instead, I ended up marrying one of the greatest pianists alive. ☺️ Ironically, I almost never play anymore because I feel silly doing so in his presence. But, when I have the entire house to myself and the piano is just sitting there… also, sorry. I don’t know how to play anything but praise songs (I used to be a praise team leader at youth group), lol.

node.text:
Yesterday’s post sparked a very interesting conversation in the comments regarding food access and privilege. This is one of the best things about tKV Community—we can be civil and compassionate with disparate points of view. This is an excerpt from my podcast with @robbie_lockie and @plantbasednews where I provide my thoughts on the “barriers to entry” to a plant based diet. I used to be one of those persons who would passionately say “but vegan diets are so much cheaper! And will lower your medical bills to boot!” But I realized after talking with many ppl—vegans and non vegans alike—that this ignores the psychic cost of radically changing your life when life is doing so freaking much to get in the way. With a global pandemic as our collective backdrop, and millions who’ve lost their jobs and even loved ones, it simply isn’t kind much less enough to say “well you can get beans and rice at chipotle for $2.” We need to do better. We can do better. 

Link to full podcast:

https://podcasts.google.com/feed/aHR0cDovL2ZlZWRzLnNvdW5kY2xvdWQuY29tL3VzZXJzL3NvdW5kY2xvdWQ6dXNlcnM6MjgxOTkzNTg0L3NvdW5kcy5yc3M/episode/dGFnOnNvdW5kY2xvdWQsMjAxMDp0cmFja3MvMTA1OTcwMTk3Nw

node.text:
I recently had the opportunity to sit down with @robbie_lockie over at @plantbasednews for their podcast and it was the first time I was able to really talk, in depth, about my choice to adopt a plant based diet, and the reason I continue to stay committed to a vegan lifestyle. I know many of you who follow me are not vegan (perhaps “plant curious”?), but it is a side to me that plays an increasingly large role in my choices and thus my identity. I view the world’s troubles—racism, poverty, war—as problems that will be rendered moot if we don’t fix the existential crisis posed by climate change. Accordingly, the ailments that surfaced over the past few years in the United States have been imbued with greater urgency. Put simply, I worry that if we don’t get honest with climate change right now, we won’t have the luxury of time to treat the other illnesses of the world.
.
I am by no means a climate activist. I come to this as much a neophyte as many of you. I still probably do a lot of things that many veteran climate experts would view as horrifying. But, I am trying to do my part to make the world not just a better place, but a viable place for all of us.
.
Throughout the past 5+ years I’ve been vegan, many people (mostly other vegans) have tried to peg me as a “vegan for health,” “vegan for the animals,” or “vegan for the planet.” I find these buckets to be unhelpful, because I’m all three or none at all, depending on the context.  I’m just me—Joanne—a girl who loves animals, who cares about her body, and who wants to ensure that our children’s children’s children get to see the world in all its unscathed beauty.
.
Thank you to Robbie and the PBN team for giving me the chance to share this side to me.  You can find this episode of the Plant Based Podcast on Sound Cloud, iTunes, or anywhere else you listen to podcasts.

node.text:
My grandmother was such a hard woman. She wasn’t like the grandmothers we saw on tv—cuddly and sweet and smelling of cinnamon. Hahlmuhnee was severe, impatient, and carried with her the scent of gochugaru. Still, my brother and I loved her fiercely.  More than anyone in my life, she made me feel safe and protected throughout the wildling days of my childhood. At night, she’d coax me to sleep with tales of tigers and sisters and the moon, but she never told me about her past. What it was like growing up. How she met her husband, my grandfather. Why she could speak Japanese. How she coped with being a young widow when her husband passed away. What it was like being a single mother in Korea. I wish I had asked her those questions, because I think there was a part of her that wanted to share them.
.
Hahlmuhnee used to make us kimbap all the time. For every road trip, every picnic, even for my lunchbox. And nothing would get me angrier than seeing the neat piles of rolled kimbap packed into the cooler, wrapped in foil. Because it meant that, once again, we wouldn’t be getting Happy Meals. But she loved making kimbap. The methodical layering of the ingredients, the gentle pressure against the bamboo, all culminating in the perfect round mouthful of everything that makes Korean food Korean food. Hahlmuhnee never ever uttered the words “I love you”—in either Korean, Japanese, or English. She didn’t have to. And now, I could eat kimbap every single day without complaint.
.
I’ve partnered with @adobe to honor #OurDearElders, and today, I honor my grandmother. My brave, ferocious, loving grandmother. Who slipped out of North Korea through swamp water and cut through the mountains on foot, all while keeping my father safe. Tell me, how do you honor your elders? How have their stories shaped you? What are some of the foods you like to eat in remembrance of those who came before you? Share how you honor them with #OurDearElders so that we can all join in on this beautiful discussion. #adobepartner

node.text: May is mental health awareness month. And it’s easy to believe that if we say all the right things, fill our lives with all the right buzzwords, our struggles will dissolve like an aspirin in a cup of water. Unfortunately, illnesses of the mind are not as straightforward as an infection or a cold. They are circuitous, elusive, and deceptive. Truth becomes sort of like a dream—you think you hold it before it evaporates with the day to day. Seeking out and committing to consistent therapy as a young adult was a crucial part of growing into a life I could participate in with my eyes wide open. But so were the soulmates who jumped into the trenches with me and dragged me out when I’d lost the strength to do so myself.

https://thekoreanvegan.com/mouthwatering-braised-tomatoes/

node.text: This is the most frequent #AskAunty question I get and honestly, I tend to think of it in the platonic sense. I’m one of those persons who really has to remind herself that not everyone is going to like me. And that’s TOTALLY OK.

node.title: Advice from 고모: when they don’t like you back...

node.text:
Several months ago, I listened in on a room in ClubHouse.  And in that room was @yutsai88. In case you don’t know who YuTsai is, he is a renown photographer, cooking show host, and activist. Everything he said in that CH room resonated so much with me and, well, his talent as an artist was indisputable. I took a risk and slid into his DMs, telling him how much of what he shared moved me. Although he followed me back on Instagram, it’s not like we talked much or became fast friends. But over the course of the next several months, I saw more of his work and he saw more of mine. And somewhere along the way, our paths crossed again, only, this time, it was intentional, and this time, we made the most of it, armed with what we’d learned about each other through our respective Instagram posts.
.
People often ask me why I share so much of what I do, how I get comfortable with being so vulnerable.  The truth is, it isn’t always comfortable. In fact, I’m often posting things that push the boundaries of both comfort and etiquette, things that might make me appear weak, sad, or hopelessly morose. But, I share these stories because there’s always that chance that it will touch someone’s heart and unlock it to reveal a kindred spirit. YuTsai’s energy is infectious, and, as evidenced by his photography, he can see things that many cannot, find beauty in the unbeautiful, capture those things that can only be conveyed in utter stillness.
.
I am so grateful for the opportunity to chat with YuTsai in his podcast, @letstalkwithyutsai where we talk about food, family, and friendship.  For the full podcast, check out the link in my bio.

node.text:
One of the most frequent requests for advice I’ve received is how to get over being “unmotivated.” It had me thinking about the time I posted a “Day in the Life” video and a fellow female lawyer commented, “It looks like you don’t work very hard.” Of course, it had me seething and the subsequent “rant” I posted was my first viral video. Ultimately, though, it got me thinking that we are in a sad state of affairs when our peers are telling us we need to work harder based upon a 60 second video.
.
I’m very familiar with being unmotivated when it comes to running. There are times when the thought of going out for a run makes me want to cry. This is particularly so when I don’t have a race, a finish line to run towards, because then, I don’t have an end in sight and the only meaning that exists is one I have to derive myself. Sometimes, our jobs can be like that. Without a clear path towards promotion or self-actualization, working day-in-and-day-out can become tiresome. However, when you add to that the prevailing deification of “productivity” that has infected our way of thinking, burn out is inevitable. Whether it’s because you’re simply attempting to avoid dealing with underlying issues, or you’ve fallen prey to the notion that 9 to 5 is for chumps, workaholism isn’t something to be proud of in and of itself. Discipline, commitment, reliability, responsiveness, and competency—these aspirational adjectives are achievable without working yourself into a nub.
.
I’m not saying that you should go to the other extreme and watch kdramas all day every day for the rest of your life. But, we have swung too hard in the opposite direction, and it’s time to restore a little balance in our lives by making room for recovery and joy instead of worshipping a race that ends with everyone getting injured.

node.text:
This post was inspired by one of my favorite Creators of all time, @sulheejessica. One of the reasons I love Jessica’s posts so much is because she packs her Bento Boxes with so much more than good food. She teaches her beautiful daughters (and, by extension, all of us) that they don’t ever need to be ashamed of their food, their heritage, or who they are.
.
Of course, not all of us has the time or wherewithal to be so intentional about packed lunches (my brother and sister-in-law are lucky if they can get my nephew to eat anything other than raspberries and pancakes). And when we were little, my parents and my grandmother couldn’t appreciate how showing up to school with rice and seaweed might make me feel a little uncomfortable, when I was already so self-conscious about not being able to speak English or having the “wrong” color eyes.  The cafeteria became one of scariest places in my school (perhaps second only to the playground): devoid of any real structure or curriculum, it was a free-for-all of judgment and the kind of cruelty that only children can deliver or feel. But, in the same vein, the cafeteria was also a place where the powerful fellowship of breaking bread—or some kimbap—could forge a unique bond.
.
I haven’t talked to Dan since I graduated high school. Our bond was thus temporary.  But… there is something of that moment from New Trier’s cafeteria that will last forever.

node.text:
ED/Addiction TW: I’ve been hesitant to call my eating issues an “addiction” because I didn’t want to, in any way, diminish the struggle that people have with substance abuse or chemical addictions. But, a few years ago, when I came to the realization that my compulsion to restrict my eating was one I’d have to fight for the rest of my life, it started to seem a lot like how people described recovering from drug addiction, cigarette addiction, alcohol addiction: the desire to consume these substances never completely subsides, so you have to be on guard, to some degree, forever.
.
@richroll recently released an excellent podcast with addiction expert, Anna Lembke, MD, and it was both illuminating and oddly soothing—like, it was ok to just admit, “yeah, what I have is an addiction, even if it’s not traditionally viewed that way.” Sometimes, naming these things can help with treating these things, you know? Or at least coping with them.
.
These days, I’ve been trying to teach myself to lean back a little—not necessarily on other people, but on the universe itself, trusting that there’s something out there that will not allow me to fall if my heart is pure.  It sounds naive and there are statistics out there that seem to prove this theory wrong—that the universe is callous and cruel. But, when you’re being asked to roll a boulder up an unending mountain, what else do you have if not the belief that your task is all part of something greater than yourself, something you can’t see, but great nonetheless? I don’t say these things to disown my mistakes, my achievements, my power—but to allow myself respite between the battles, a little break between the sprints, I suppose.
.
I don’t have all the answers, but sometimes I think that is the answer: getting comfortable with knowing there’s no easy resolution, there’s no finish line. Finding joy isn’t about stringing together an endless chain of happy moments; rather, it is an anchor that allows you to ride the waves of both elation and crushing disappointment, while always coming home.

node.text:
Even though I’m constantly encouraging people to carve out and walk their own paths, the truth is, I’ve lived pretty much my entire life desperately seeking my parents’ approval. When I was growing up, there was nothing like the high of seeing my parents proud of me. And, conversely, my parents’ disappointment—over a bad grade, making a mistake at a piano recital, or not getting into an Ivy League college--it was so painful, so depressing, it was no wonder I spent so much energy doing everything I could to avoid it.
.
I think many of us can feel this prevailing pressure, one that has been around for so long that we barely even notice it. That is, until we attempt to remove it. On the one hand, it sounds liberating, but in all honesty, doing what I knew would make my parents proud of me offered me a sense of structure, purpose, and direction. I never had to figure out what I wanted to do for myself, and being faced with that prospect is all of a sudden daunting. Who am I if not my parents’ daughter? What do I want if not what they want for me? And why have I decided to step out of the path they worked to carve for me, and straight into the shadows of this ominous mountain of uncertainty?
.
When I think about everything my parents have sacrificed to bring me to the foot of this mountain, I feel all the more humbled, even embarrassed. How dare I? Am I dishonoring them by choosing to strike out on my own, do something completely at odds with the predictability of paychecks, refuting, on its face, the truth that carried them to the United States—that work is not meant to be fun, but hard, back-breaking, even degrading, at times, because that is what you need to do in order to survive?
.
I like to believe, too, though, that it is everyone’s dream to be able to have impact while doing something you love. That success can be something more than mere survival. And that when my Mom and Dad came to the US upon the promise of the American dream, they did so to ensure my inheritance included the audacity to not just climb the mountain, but to move it.

node.text: I am that girl who cries at coffee commercials, that one episode of Fresh Prince, Mufasa’s tragic end, and Beethoven’s 9th. I can’t watch other people cry without crying too. And yes, I get mad/upset/sad over things that some might think are “trivial.” If only I had a nickel for every time someone told me “god you’re making such a big deal out of nothing”…. I find this to be the most useless thing you can say to someone who is in distress. It not only completely dismisses the person’s pain, it delegitimizes it and, in some cases, infantilizes the person who had the courage to share themselves to begin with. It ultimately deters people from sharing their actual feelings and, more perniciously, prevents them from confronting their grief. Grief, loss, pain—these are a part of life and shutting your eyes to them will not make them go away. There is nothing brave about pretending you don’t feel hurt when something bad happens. But there’s something beautifully brave about facing the hurt and learning to live with it, grow from it. So, instead of making it “cool” to dismiss people’s pain, act all tough and pompous, I’m on a mission to make it “cool” to be compassionate, empathetic, kind. Because we need a lot more of these things in order to make sure that we all leave the world a better place than when we entered it. Also, yes, I will be posting the recipe for this bowl soon!

node.text:
I often receive emails from followers with requests for advice. I’m very hesitant about responding to individuals mostly because I’m not a professional and I almost never have adequate information to provide sound, ethical counsel on issues that can literally change a person’s life. While I can’t tell you what to do, I can draw upon my own personal experience with similar issues, with the hope of lending you perspective.
.
I have received countless emails from people who, by all appearances, are stuck in abusive relationships, and yet… they are reluctant to leave. On the one hand, we are taught to believe that abuse is never acceptable, but on the other hand, we are also trained to think that quitting is almost as bad. Don’t get me wrong—love takes enormous work, commitment, patience, and humility.  These aren’t things that come naturally to anyone, and therefore, endurance is certainly a factor in love. And perhaps because of that, we start to redefine our boundaries, amend the rules or ignore them altogether, because we’d rather rationalize than resign.
.
However, loving someone is NOT mutually exclusive from loving yourself.  You must protect the sanctity of your own heart, because your love for others—your spouse, your children, your parents, your friends, your community—is only as powerful and healthy as the heart that fuels it. When I walked into my therapist’s office many years ago, she warned me, “learning to love yourself will be the hardest thing you ever do.”
.
Yes, love is hard. But oh my dear… You are worth it.

node.text:
When I was 14 years old, I wrote a letter to my 24 year old self. And in it, I asked 24 year old me whether I’d married “him.” Although I hadn’t yet married “him” at 24, I would marry him at 26. I remember being so proud of the fact that I could tell 14 year old me, “I haven’t married him yet, but I got him,” as if I’d nabbed a prize winning trout at summer camp or something. Of course, I never revisited that conversation when I divorced “him” at 35. And now, when I think of that letter, I think it’s silly, I think myself silly.
.
It’s easy to look back on ourselves, our mistakes, and be critical.  And sometimes, it’s actually hard to be proud of our achievements, because doing so opens us up to accusations of being “cocky” “arrogant” or, for women, “unladylike” and “immodest.” I’m not proud of how ardently I attached my identity to a man’s affection for so much of my life and I wish I could say that I was one of those young ladies who knew her worth from an early age. But the truth is, it took me a long time to understand that my value should only be measured independently from anyone else, including any man.
.
I am, however, proud of what I have achieved—professionally, athletically, creatively.  But, after doing a little thinking today, I concluded that one of the things I’m most proud of is my protective instinct, the willingness to say or do the right thing even when it’s a little scary or unpopular, because it’s on behalf of someone who isn’t capable of saying or doing it themselves. And I hope my family and friends love that about me, too.
.
Who did you become? And what’s one aspect of that person that you’re most proud of?
